title: Windows: TLS revocation check fails for dynamic certs
description:
On Windows, clients using Schannel (native TLS) fail to connect through the proxy.

**Symptoms:**
- curl: explicit error `CRYPT_E_NO_REVOCATION_CHECK (0x80092012)`
- Claude CLI: hangs silently (may be same root cause, unconfirmed)

**Workaround:**
- curl: `--ssl-no-revoke` flag works
- Claude CLI: unknown

**Likely cause:**
Langley's dynamically generated certificates lack CRL Distribution Points and OCSP responder extensions. Windows Schannel requires these for revocation checking.

**Potential fixes:**
1. Add CRL/OCSP extensions to generated certs (complex)
2. Document workaround for Windows users
3. Investigate if there's a way to mark certs as "no revocation check needed"

**Repro:**
```powershell
certutil -addstore -f "ROOT" $env:APPDATA\langley\certs\ca.crt
$env:HTTPS_PROXY="http://localhost:9090"
curl -x http://localhost:9090 https://httpbin.org/get  # fails
curl --ssl-no-revoke -x http://localhost:9090 https://httpbin.org/get  # works
```
close_reason: Fixed by adding CRL Distribution Point to generated certs and serving CRL at /crl/ca.crl

title: Frontend dev server cannot be gracefully stopped on Windows
description:
When running 'make dev-frontend' on Windows, the Vite dev server cannot be stopped with Ctrl+C. The terminal shows 'Terminate batch job (Y/N)?' but answering Y does not cleanly stop it - the terminal becomes unresponsive and must be force killed.

This happens because:
1. Make spawns a subprocess for npm/vite
2. Ctrl+C signal handling on Windows does not propagate cleanly to child processes
3. The terminal gets into a bad state after the parent process exits

Repro:
1. Run 'make dev-frontend'
2. Press Ctrl+C
3. Answer Y to 'Terminate batch job'
4. Terminal becomes unresponsive, must close and reopen
close_reason: Added make stop workaround - Windows make doesn't propagate Ctrl+C

title: 3.3 Token UX: Origin + Cookie auth
description:
Replace manual token copy/paste with automatic Origin + Cookie auth.

Design:
1. Check Origin header is localhost (http://localhost:*, http://127.0.0.1:*)
2. If no origin (non-browser): require Authorization header (CLI/automation)
3. If valid origin + no cookie: set HTTP-only session cookie, process request
4. If valid origin + valid cookie: process request

Cookie spec:
- Name: langley_session
- HttpOnly: true
- Secure: false (localhost)
- SameSite: Strict
- Path: /

Security layers:
- Layer 1: Origin header must be localhost
- Layer 2: Valid session cookie required
- Layer 3: HTTP-only prevents XSS
- Layer 4: SameSite=Strict prevents CSRF
- Automation: Authorization: Bearer <LANGLEY_AUTH_TOKEN> still works

Acceptance:
- [ ] Non-localhost origins rejected with 401
- [ ] First localhost request auto-sets HTTP-only cookie
- [ ] Subsequent requests authenticated via cookie
- [ ] No JavaScript token handling in dashboard
- [ ] No manual token copy/paste required
- [ ] LANGLEY_AUTH_TOKEN header still works for CLI/automation
- [ ] WebSocket auth updated to use same mechanism
- [ ] Playwright test for auth flow
close_reason: Implemented Origin + Cookie auth. Zero manual token handling required for browser access.

title: SEC-HIGH: GET /auth returns client_secret in response body - credential exposure risk
description:
Phase 3.3 proposes GET /auth returning {client_id, client_secret} in response. Even localhost-only, this means:
1. Client secret visible in browser DevTools Network tab
2. Logged in any request logging middleware
3. Cached in browser history if URL has query params
4. Violates OAuth2 best practice where client_secret should never be transmitted to browser
close_reason: Obsolete: OAuth design replaced with Origin + Cookie auth

title: SPEC-GAP: Missing client identification mechanism in OAuth flow

1. How is 'this client' identified on first visit?
2. Is it by Origin header? User-Agent? IP?
3. What prevents credential farming (attacker generating many credentials)?
4. How does server correlate localStorage client_id with server-side record?
close_reason: Obsolete: OAuth design replaced with Origin + Cookie auth

title: Implement LiteLLM pricing integration
description:
Replace hardcoded pricing with LiteLLM's maintained pricing database.

## Context
Current pricing is hardcoded in sqlite.go schema (only 5 Anthropic models, stale data). LiteLLM maintains a comprehensive pricing JSON covering 100+ models across all providers.

## Source
https://github.com/BerriAI/litellm/blob/main/model_prices_and_context_window.json

Fields available:
- input_cost_per_token, output_cost_per_token
- cache_creation_input_token_cost, cache_read_input_token_cost
- litellm_provider (maps to our provider field)
- max_input_tokens, max_output_tokens

## Implementation
1. Fetch JSON from GitHub raw URL on startup
2. Cache locally with TTL (e.g., 24h)
3. Parse and populate pricing table (or use in-memory map)
4. Match flow's model name to lookup costs
5. Fallback gracefully if fetch fails (use cached/bundled version)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Remove hardcoded pricing from schema
- [ ] Fetch LiteLLM pricing JSON on startup
- [ ] Cache with configurable TTL
- [ ] Cost calculation works for Anthropic, OpenAI, Bedrock, Gemini
- [ ] Graceful fallback if network unavailable
- [ ] Log when pricing data is refreshed

## Files
- internal/store/sqlite.go (remove hardcoded INSERT)
- internal/analytics/analytics.go (GetPricing)
- NEW: internal/pricing/litellm.go (fetch + parse)
